stem: The epidemiologist nurse is investigating a clusters of jaundice in a local community. Based on the documentation in the Transmission Risk Assessment, match each client with the most likely Hepatitis type and primary prevention.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient 1: 45y/o male. Recently attended a large banquet where several other guests report 'stomach flu' and jaundice. 
Patient 2: 22y/o female. Reports she 'lost a needle' while sharing drugs with friends. 
Patient 3: 30y/o female. Husband was just diagnosed with jaundice and they do not use protection during intercourse.

tabs.title: Transmission Risk Assessment
tabs.content:
PatientPrimary ExposureIncubation Phase
1Ingested raw shellfish at banquetShort (2-6 weeks)
2Parenteral (Needle-stick)Long (6-24 weeks)
3Sexual / Mucosal ContactVariable (Blood-borne)

tabs.title: Physical Findings
tabs.content: All patients presenting with dark urine and clay-colored stools.

rows.text: Prevention: Hand hygiene and safe food preparation
Prevention: Avoiding shared equipment and safe sex

rationale.correct: Hepatitis A (c1) is transmitted through the fecal-oral route, often linked to contaminated food like raw shellfish (r1); prevention is primarily via hand hygiene (r3). Hepatitis B and C (c2) are blood-borne and sexually transmitted (r2); prevention focuses on avoiding contaminated needles or fluids (r4).
clinicalPearls: Hep A = Vowels in the Bowels.
Hep B = Blood and Body fluids.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that only A and E come from the bowel. Everything else (B, C, D) is blood-borne.
